qas.question: What was General Hodge appointed the head of?

answers.text: United States Army Military Government in Korea

qas.question: What government was not recognized by the U.S. Army Military Government in Korea?
Why was the People's Republic of Korea not recognized?
Who did General Hodge restore power to, resulting in protests?

context: On 8 September 1945, U.S. Lt. <a0_0>Gen. John R. Hodge<a0_0/> arrived in Incheon to accept the Japanese surrender south of the 38th parallel. Appointed as military governor, General Hodge directly controlled South Korea as head of the <a1_0>United States Army Military Government in Korea<a1_0/> (USAMGIK 1945–48). He established control by restoring to power the key <a4_0>Japanese colonial administrators<a4_0/>, but in the face of Korean protests he quickly reversed this decision. The USAMGIK refused to recognize the provisional government of the short-lived <a2_0>People's Republic of Korea<a2_0/> (PRK) because it suspected <a3_0>it was communist<a3_0/>.
